reviewText: I have waited years to have this out on DVD and have just purchased it. The "twist and turns" will stay with you....truly a story that will surface in your memory over and over. Forget popcorn, this story line will surely give you food for thought. Viable life lessons to ponder even today.
summary: One of the Best Kept Secrets in Movies

reviewText: BETWEEN TWO WORLDS was adapted by Daniel Fuchs, the writer ofCRISS CROSS(1949),PANIC IN THE STREETS(1950) andSTORM WARNING(1951). Fuchs won an Oscar for scriptingLOVE ME OR LEAVE ME(1955), the biopic of Ruth Etting that starred Doris Day and Jimmy Cagney..None-too-subtle bashing of capitalism, as we see in this movie, was popular during WWII and the early post-war years but there was soon a response: the HUAC investigations of Hollywood and a dogged search for "fellow travelers." John Garfield was one of those caught in this trap. Perhaps the stress of being a suspected "Red" hastened the coronary that claimed him at a too-young age.Occasional over-melodramatic touches in "Between Two Worlds" don't detract much from an interesting supernatural fantasy involving a group of dead folks sailing on a fogbound sea toward their fates. To my mind, this is Garfield's best film work. His unemployed reporter Tom Prior is flippant and word-playful (in a morose sort of way). Tom can't wait to shock everyone with the news that they are all dead, and he uses a pistol to demonstrate it.Miss Emerson plays a caricature: the cynical "fallen" woman who tries cleaning up her act before she's judged. Henreid and Parker, as the disabled pianist and his devoted wife, bear the lion's share of this picture's pathos, but Miss Allgood gets a chance to turn on our waterworks after she's been declared worthy of a little seaside cottage with a white picket fence. We also sympathize with the unlucky merchant marine (Tobias) who will never see his newborn son.Elsom and Emery are a too-long married couple. He's a good egg who for years has quietly tolerated his wife's endless nagging. King is  Reverend Duke, a shy cleric who's never been beyond his own parish. Duke thinks he's off on an adventure to America, but he's really just cruising toward Judgment Day. The ship's steward, Scrubby (Gwenn), is caught in limbo by his own doings. He's made this voyage to nowhere countless thousands of times.Greenstreet's Thompson the Examiner is a no-nonsense type. As an example, he immediately sends to hell the film's most repugnant character, an arrogant industrialist named Lingley (Coulouris), after the man demands his trial NOW. Greenstreet's icy response: "You've already HAD your trial" and the befuddled multi-millionaire is led away, defeated, deflated and finally silent.This film is based on Sutton Vane's stageplay, "Outward Bound." The original 1930 movie adaptation featured Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Leslie Howard, Montagu Love, Alison Skipworth (one of my favorite character actresses), and Dudley Digges as the Examiner..Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.(7.3) Between Two Worlds (1944) - John Garfield/Paul Henreid/Eleanor Parker/Sydney Greenstreet/Edmund Gwenn/George Tobias/George Coulouris/Sara Allgood/Dennis King/Isobel Elsom/Gilbert Emery

reviewText: Well, I have to buy this movie.  I've remembered it, or thought I dreamed it, since I saw it many years ago on TV.  All I remembered was that Sydney Greenstreet was in it and thought so was Peter Lorrie but don't see him listed.....I remember the storyline somewhat and also do remember the ending....I don't think you'll be dissatisfied if you buy it because when there's a movie, and there aren't that many, that stay with you 20-30 years,it's just a good movie. I can't speak to the quality of the DVD because I haven't received it yet - just bought it this minute...but I'm so looking forward to seeing it again after all this time. If I were to compare how this movie stayed with me to other movies I've seen, The Rapture with Mimi Rodgers comes to mind....So does Horse Whisperer and Exodus....Gosford Park....guess I could go on and you see this list is highly eclectic.....All I can do is recommend that you try it, especially if you like film noir...

reviewText: "Between Two Worlds" is one of those  "final judgment" films that periodically gain populartity. Examples of this genre include "The Devil and Daniel Webster" (1941), "Defending Your Life" (1991), "Heart and Souls" (1993), and "Shortcut to Happiness" (2004). It stars John Garfield, Paul Henreid, Sydney Greenstreet and Eleanor Parker with Edmund Gwenn, George Tobias and Faye Emerson. It was based on a 1924 play "Outward Bound" (and the 1930 movie of the same name) that was revived in 1938 under the direction of Otto Preminger. Look for the original title in the first scene of the film.The plot is simple - a group of strangers find themselves mysteriously on a ship. Turns out they all recently died and at the end of the voyage their fates will be sealed, a fact that we and the passengers themselves slowly learn. The film is set in World War 2 England but this is a mere convenience - neither the war nor England feature prominently in the plot. Jack Warner hated the Nazis, and the war years spawned a large number of war related films, so the link is not merely coincidental.The film stars ruggedly handsome John  Garfield (1913-52), the original "method" actor. Garfield made his screen debut in 1938 with the popular "Four Daughters" for which he received his first Best Supporting  Actor nomination (he got his second in 1947 for "Body and Soul"), and "They Made me a Criminal" (1939) propelled him into the A list. He's best known for "The Postman Always Rings Twice" (1946). Blacklisted in the communist scare of the early 50s, his career was cut short, and he died in 1952 at age 39. This film comes at the height of his popularity. He plays a wise cracking newspaperman.Paul Henreid (1905-92) will forever be the besieged Victor Laszlo from "Casablanca" (1942) or Jerry Durrance lighting two cigarettes at once from "Now Voyager" (1942), despite his more than 40 other films. Henried, like Garfield, was also a victim of the communist scare and was blacklisted as an actor, turning his attentions to directing and work on stage. Henreid plays a pianist. Curiously enough he is waiting for an exit permit in this film as he was in "Casablanca".Sydney Greenstreet (1879-1954) is everyone's favorite fat man despite having made only 22 films and his film career lasted a mere 8 years. But these films included "The Maltese Falcon" (for which he was nominated for an Oscar), "Casablanca", "They Died with Their Boots On", and "Passage to Marseille".Eleanor Parker (1922- ) is probably best known for her role as the Baroness in "The Sound of Music" (1965). She was nominated 3 times for an Oscar ("Caged", "Detective Story", and "Interrupted Melody") and once for an Emmy ("The Eleventh Hour") and a Golden Globe ("Bracken's World"). Parker plays Henreid's wife, and while she does seem a little overdramatic, it's not in retrospect.Edmund Gwenn (1877-1959) will forever be everyone's Santa Claus from his Oscar winning performance in "Miracle on 34th Street" (1947), but this was only one of nearly 100 films he made, including "Mister 880" (1950), "Les Miserables" (1952), "Them" (1954), Sylvia Scarlett" (1935), and "A Yank at Oxford" (1938). Gwenn belongs to that small group of fat unattractive men who became stars. Gwenn plays the ship's steward.George Tobias (1901-1980) appeared in more than 50 films including "The Strawberry Blonde" (1941),  "Yankee Doodle Dandy" (1942), and "Passage to Marseille" (1944). Like many other film actors, he transitioned to TV in the 50s and is best remembered for his comedy as the witch Samantha's neighbor Abner on "Bewitched" (1964-71). Tobias plays a merchant sailor.Glamorous Faye Emerson (1917-1983) achieved her fame on TV in the 50s, but she had an active film career and worked with Garfield in films like "Nobody Lives Forever" (1946) and "Out of the Fog" (1941). Emerson plays an actress.Performances are uniformly good. The direction is uninspired. This was director Edward Blatt's (1903-1991) first film and he made only 2 more before abandoning his film career and moving to TV and Broadway as a producer. Another problem is that the film is basically a translation from the play, so the settings are limited.Jack Warner took a personal interest in the film and served as executive producer.Writer/producer Mark Hellinger (1903-47) was the line producer.  Hellinger is credited with 22 films including "The Naked City" (1948), "Brute Force" (1947), "The Killers" (1946), "High Sierra" (1941), and "They Drive By Night" (1940).  Richard Brooks novel "The Producers" is based on Hellinger's life.Erich Wolfgang Korngold (1897-1957) composed. Korngold made more than 20 films, was nominated 3 times for an Oscar and won once ("Robin Hood" in 1938). He did most of Errol Flynn's swashbucklers. The music moves in and out of focus in a good way and helps propel the plot.1944 was not a strong year for films. "Going my Way" was the big multiple Oscar winner.  "Gaslight" did well at the box office and won Ingrid Bergman an Oscar. Other notable films were Judy Garland's "Meet me in St Louis", "Double Indemnity", "To Have and Have Not", "Arsenic and Old Lace", and "Lifeboat".This is certainly a good film although for this genre I am more of a fan of "Heart and Souls". Still, with such a great cast the film is definitely worth viewing.

reviewText: Once more, this film represents the studio system (Warners Brothers) in its finest light producing quality work on a low budget (previously filmed in the 30s) script with actors, young and old, from its stable of talent very deep. Today it is fantasy to match a script to a competent director in this period of director stars. Nonetheless, this is an inspiring story, lifted higher by the lush musical score by Korngold, that shifts from the earth-bound to the otherworld with ease, serving the needs of its varied cast of characters representing Everyman. I can only explain the absence of this enchanting yarn from afternoon TV viewing the past 40 years as intentional neglect. Even though the fantasy films of Michael Powell of the 40s got more play, this rivals his imaginative work but stands above them by its sharp-paced script, allowing all actors to shine. You are transported to this other world, aboard a nameless liner, moving on a cloud bank with all rank of society in close quarters. Did they all die? Where are they going? What is life? What is fate?  John Garfield, Paul Henreid, George Coulouris, Faye Emerson, Edmund Gwenn and the large Sydney Greenstreet keep you interested to its surprising, uplifting climax. Will they have a second chance? What are their options? Is justice the same beyond earth? I will not spoil it for you. From the first explosion in an English city during WWII to the confinement aboard a liner it all moves quickly to the end; believe me, you will feel like you are trapped in Rick's café the characters are made so believable until Mr. Greenstreet shows up to ramp up the excitement. Rod Serling definitely took notes from this film from the Warner vaults, if only our justice system could be as inspiring. Hankies are required and do not feel foolish by replaying the scene where Mr. Greenstreet enters.

reviewText: Here and there, perhaps a SPOILER or two for BETWEEN TWO WORLDS and OUTWARD BOUND.1944's BETWEEN TWO WORLDS remakes the 1930 film OUTWARD BOUND but veers away in one very key matter. OUTWARD BOUND sustains its air of mystery by delaying the big narrative swerve until deep into the story. In BETWEEN TWO WORLDS the viewer is alerted very early on that something otherworldly is in the works, thus stripping the film of what would have been a tremendous plot twist. Either way, either version, it's a fine allegorical tale. But I do count OUTWARD BOUND to be the superior product. If nothing else, Leslie Howard is in it.Negotiating the waters between life and death, between heaven and hell, is a mysterious steamship, crossing to America under perilous wartime conditions. Ten people - most of them oblivious fatalies of a London air raid - find themselves the only passengers onboard this otherwise desolate ship that is crewless but for an old steward. As you may imagine, a disconcerting, dreamlike atmosphere is soon fostered.John Garfield puts his own brooding spin on surly foreign correspondent Tom Prior (originally played by Howard), he of the cynic's persuasion and the agitator's mindset. Tom Prior is one of those lost souls who doesn't believe in anything. But he's a clever one, and he's got that newspaperman's dogged instincts. So it's disappointing that he doesn't get to suss out what's really going on. No, he overhears the big reveal.BETWEEN TWO WORLDS, like its predecessor, is a character study, only with a surreal element. Think of it as GRAND HOTEL with a macabre twist and a World War II backdrop. John Garfield is fine as the lead, but this is also an all-star cast of great character actors, most notably Sydney Greenstreet and Edmund Gwenn. This time out, Paul Heinreid and Eleanor Parker are the star-crossed lovers, he the traumatized concert pianist, she his adoring girl. Faye Emerson is very good as the jaded actress who seizes one last chance at, well, if not happiness, then financial security. Only to learn that it's all moot.A manic and in-the-know Tom Prior ridicules and eggs on his fellow passengers, and maybe you're supposed to write him off at some point, he proves to be so mean. The compelling third act devotes itself to revealing each of the passengers' destinations. It's this late in the game that Sydney Greenstreet makes his appearance, and he's as authoritative as ever as the examiner tasked with passing judgment on this latest batch of souls. By the way, I sort of had an inkling that the priest in the ranks was going to be just fine. But that ruthless corporate executive (George Coulouris)... tsk, tsk... Whereas we can predict what happens to most of the passengers, the ultimate fates of three people remain in doubt throughout. Garfield's character has lived a misspent life. He's putting up a brave front. He knows what's coming to him now. How can he possibly gain redemption at this late hour? And what of the star-crossed lovers, them what committed a grievous sin? BETWEEN TWO WORLDS is a handsome production, governed by a polished script, supported by several substantial performances, invigorated by unsettling mood and tone. I thought Edmund Gwenn as the sad-eyed steward Scrubby and Sydney Greenstreet as the no-nonsense examiner lent tremendous gravitas to the picture. I still like OUTWARD BOUND better.
summary: "It's late, later than you know. Dogs bark, children scream, mothers weep. This is the Judgment Day."

reviewText: The title of the film ("Between Two Worlds") is symbolic of what we might refer to in "psycho-spiritual" terms as the "After Death Experience," when the soul has suddenly been released from the body and finds itself temporarily trapped in a contextual limbo between the physical world and the "Hereafter".On board a fog-enshrouded ocean liner, with neither captain nor crew, several assorted (deceased) passengers -- each representing a unique life-affirming (or life-denying) value he or she  elected to live by while on earth -- find themselves facing the grim task of self-evaluation, aided by the inimitable Sydney Greenstreet in his memorable role as "The Examiner".Just feast your eyes on the sterling cast of characters featured in the film: JOHN GARFIELD (disgruntled cynic, blaming everyone but himself for his "bad breaks"); PAUL HENREID (former brilliant pianist and despairing "suicide," whose fingers were crippled during the war); ELEANOR PARKER (so passionately in love with Henreid, she chooses to "die" with him); SYDNEY GREENSTREET (an angel sent to render "Final Judgement" to those on board); EDMUND GWENN ("Scrubby" -- a suicide, condemned to sail throughout eternity as the ship's steward, preparing the way for those recently departed souls); GEORGE COULOURIS (unforgettable as the villainous "Mr. Lingley of Lingley Limited"); FAYE EMERSON (aspiring actress, searching in all the wrong places for fame and fortune); GEORGE TOBIAS (typical, easy-to-please Mr. Average Guy, and a thoroughly honorable, good-natured human being), DENNIS KING (timid, apprehensive priest, who feared to live life to the fullest); SARA ALLGOOD (tender, adoring mother to one of the unaware passengers on board), ISOBEL ELSOM (high-society woman with a perpetual air of disdaining snobbery); GILBERT EMERY (staunchly devoted, but abused and humiliated, husband of Elsom).Rather than sit here vainly endeavoring to come up with the "Mother of All Praises" for this haunting, relatively little known film, let me simply confess that I've watched BETWEEN TWO WORLDS at least a dozen times during the course of my life -- and I'm ready to sit down right now and watch it again.Why?Bcause it never fails to satisfy.
summary: A Minor Masterpiece That Demands Rewatching!

reviewText: I saw "Between Two Worlds" decades ago and I never forgot the experience. This film has a powerful message about what the afterlife could be like. The memorable performance of Hollywood's Golden Era, All-Star cast, John Garfield, Eleanor Parker, Sydney Greenstreet, Edmund Gwenn and others will remain on your memory forever. The release of this old Hollywood blockbuster was long overdue.I am very happy that it is finally available for the benefit of all of us who saw it many years ago and never forgot it and those who have not seen it.Definitely one of the most important film re-issues of all times.

reviewText: This is a 1944 re-make of the 1930's motion picture, "OUTWARD BOUND."The premise is that a group of mostly unknown-to-each-other people, while traveling by motorcar (in London UK) are hit by a bomb which has (supposedly) been dropped on/near them, by the Nazi Luftwaffe, during WW II.  They were on their way to board a cruise ship that was headed to the USA, so they aren't surprised at all, when they suddenly find themselves aboard a cruise ship that is sailing amidst a strange fog.What they don't yet know, is that all of them were killed by that bomb and they are sailing to their judgment, to be examined/interviewed by a clergyman (actor Sydney Greenstreet) who will inform them where they will go, to spend all eternity.Three people aboard that ship know the truth about their status and destination, but two of them (a loving couple who committed suicide) are requested by the third person (the steward/purser of the ship) to not reveal the truth to the others.  The couple agrees to remain silent about that.Eventually, the others discover the truth and learn their respective fates.I don't know exactly why I love this movie so much, but I guess it might be because it causes me to believe that there just might be something "beyond" our Earthly existence, and that if there really is an "afterlife," perhaps decent folks (like myself?) will have nothing to fear, when their own life is over.

reviewText: A strange but good fantasy  Suppose you find yourself on a cruise ship with a mix of different foiks-only your dead.they let you be yourself without telling you what's happening. Only thing one person is aware he is dead. They later come to make the final judgment on your life, which will determend your final resting place. It's intresting as you see this fine cast find out how they will spend thier days. Including a women who will get a mansion, but no guest allowed. and how one who commited suicide learns he never will leave the boat.  It's not a film I can watch often , but still worth having.

reviewText: Why this atmospheric, philosophical gem isn't better known is beyond me, because it offers both gripping entertainment & plenty of food for thought afterward. In its allegorical story of 10 souls sailing into Eternity, bound either for a self-made Heaven or Hell, it poses questions we should be asking ourselves everyday. For example, the loathsome yet somehow pathetic Mr. Lingley, man of such wealth & power, finds that neither avails him in the afterlife. In being told that while he might have thought he had everything, now he has nothing, the unspoken question is: How much did he ever really have in life? Did all that wealth & power compensate for the lack of love & humanity?And so it is with all the characters. While they must face an Examiner, their final judgment has already been made by their own choices in life. Whether you're a believer in any religious system, or a believer in none, the question of living a truly meaningful life remains an important one -- perhaps THE most important one. And we're not only faced with that question every day that we wake up, we're given another day to answer it, perhaps this time more positively than the last. Or not, as the case may be. In the end, it's really up to each of us, isn't it?The film itself is a pleasure to watch, with a fine cast of accomplished actors, a strong script, wonderful music from Erich Korngold, and a haunting backdrop of fog -- or clouds? -- through which the elegant but nearly empty ship is sailing, with not a swell or storm to disturb its passengers as they slowly realize where they are & where they're going. If the dialogue occasionally reveals its stage origins , that really doesn't matter, as the story benefits from a slightly stylized tone. The mood is sustained beautifully, with a welcome touch of humor at times, and some crackling verbal fireworks from John Garfield. His sheer presence adds so much!It's a film perfect for watching alone & then mulling over quietly ... but it's also perfect for more than one, as it'll undoubtedly leave any group discussing what's been shown & what it implies. For the thoughtful viewer, most highly recommended!
summary: Two worlds, and both of them this one
